MORTON</nameText></person></author></nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">FIREFIGHTERS are on scene at a forest fire that is burning west of Bathurst near The Rocks.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Crews received a call out to the fire at 5.15pm on Monday.</p><p>NSW Rural Fire Service (RFS) spokesperson Ben Shepherd said the 21 hectare blaze is burning through steep terrain.</p><p>"There are three trucks there and one dozer [on site] ... it is currently being controlled," he said.</p><p>"The suspected cause appears to be lightning."</p><p>Mr Shepherd said currently there is no risk to property.</p><p>NSWRFS crew also remain on scene at a separate forest fire burning near Barrakee Road at Black Springs.</p><p>This fire began on Monday at 4.55pm, but by 8pm crews from eight RFS trucks had contained the blaze.</p><p>Mr Shepherd said three trucks of firefighters remain on scene to patrol the area and ensure any hot spots are "blacked out".</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier identifierScheme="DOC-ID">WSTADV-3730673</dc:identifier><dc:source Melbourne, Werribee and Healesville zoos will all take part in exploring what is great about animals and the environment. Children younger than 16 are free. The program starts on March 30, from 9am to 5pm. Details: zoo.org.au/wildabout</p><p nitf:lede="true">Planned burns CFA and Forest Fire Management Victoria firefighters will start planned burns across Victoria. FFM Victoria chief fire officer Stephanie Rotarangi said that throughout autumn residents might smell smoke from planned burns and some roads and parks could close.Details: ffm.vic.gov.au/plannedburn, or download the VicEmergency app.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier Details: ffm.vic.gov.au/plannedburn</p><p>Phone scams The ACCC is warning people to watch out for scammers who are trying to con their victims into paying for scams with Apple iTunes gift cards. This year, reports to the ACCC's Scamwatch show 1236 people lost almost $540,000 to scammers using gift cards as payments. Details: scamwatch.gov.au</p><p>Gem exhibitionThe annual Waverley Gem Club exhibition is being held at the Brandon Park Community Centre from September 23 to 24. It will include jewellery, gemstones and crystals. Details: Gwen on 0407 512 883.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier 'All of our preparations, from hazard reduction burning in state forests to training, are a reminder we're taking no chances in our preparation,' Mr Wade said.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier identifierScheme="DOC-ID">DLYADR-3492676</dc:identifier><dc:source urn:contentItem:5MW0-HB21-JD3N-54CB-00000-00<published>2017-02-14T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T16:07:55Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>NEWS</positionSection><positionSequence>Pg. 5</positionSequence></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">Train troubles V/Line trains on the Bendigo line have delivered their lowest results for punctuality in 11"months, according to figures released by Public Transport Victoria last week. The 95.2 per cent of trains on time in January is better than 89 per cent from the same time last year, but 3"per cent lower than the 12-month average on the line.</p><p>Speed signs New $200,000 electronic flashing speed signs will be installed at Mt Macedon Primary School. Confirmation of"the new lights came during a visit by State Roads Minister Luke Donnellan and Macedon state Labor MP Mary-Anne Thomas earlier this month. School principal Trish Hyland told the Leader the lights would make crossing the road safer for the school's 125 students. The new safety lights will be switched on during Term 2 and operate from 8-9.30am and 2.30-4pm.</p><p>Fire breakA 30m fire break has been established around the Mount Macedon Memorial Cross. Forest Fire Management Victoria cleared trees and vegetation on steep slopes to the south and west of the memorial that pose the greatest risk during a fire.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:5JC8-V201-JD67-10V8-00000-00<published>2016-03-22T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T16:07:55Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>NEWS</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">ILLEGALLY dumped rubbish will be removed from the White Swan State Forest and Nerrina Heritage park next month, in a bid to clear up the heavily polluted area. </p><p>Volunteers are needed for the joint Four Wheel Drive Victoria, DELWP and Parks Victoria initiative. The rubbish was discovered in phase one of the project late last year. On April 2 and 3 volunteers will remove the rubbish and create awareness of the scourge of illegal dumping. </p><p>Four Wheel Drive Victoria project officer Kate Waller said the clean up would create awareness of the impact of illegally dumped rubbish. </p><p> 'Our enthusiastic volunteers will again donate their time to collect and remove the huge amount of waste including car bodies, white goods, couches, mattresses and general household rubbish,' Ms Waller said. </p><p>Forest Fire Management Grampians regional manager Amanda Carabott said the clean up would make a big difference to forest areas. </p><p>'We can increase awareness about the impact of illegally dumped rubbish at the same time.' </p><p>To volunteer contact Ms Waller on 9857 5209.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier identifierScheme="DOC-ID">BALCOU-3805690</dc:identifier><dc:source xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">A TRUCK driver had a lucky escape after his prime mover caught fire near Heywood on Saturday, causing $180,000 damage.</p><p>Heywood police Acting Sergeant Mark McLean said the driver of the B-double was on his way from Portland to Naracoorte to pick up a load of woodchips when he noticed smoke about 4.40pm.</p><p>The driver pulled over and grabbed his fire extinguisher, but by then it was too late and the truck was well alight, he said.</p><p>Acting Sergeant McLean said an electrical fault sparked the blaze which destroyed the prime mover and caused $180,000 damage.</p><p>He said the Lyons fire brigade was able to the extinguish the blaze and prevent it from spreading to the two trailers. </p><p>'The driver pulled over into one of the only spots where it wouldn't have caused a forest fire,' Acting Sergeant McLean said.</p><p>'It's fortunate it caught fire where it did and when it did.'</p><p>He said there were few safe spots to pull over because there were steep drop-offs along much of that section of the road. </p><p>The driver was uninjured and traffic was disrupted on the Princes Highway until about 1pm.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">Eurobodalla volunteers have been sent to help out embattled colleagues fighting three fires in the Tumut district.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Leading a strike team of 17 volunteers from Eurobodalla branches is Broulee group leader Paul Cannon.</p><p nitf:lede="true">The team includes firefighters from his own crew and the Moruya, Malua Bay, Batemans Bay, Durras and Dalmeny brigades.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Tumut has three fires burning in its local government area, including a 2675 ha scrub fire and a grass fire of more than 1000 ha. </p><p nitf:lede="true">Both are now listed as being controlled.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Far South Coast community safety officer Marty Webster said easing weather conditions meant plans to send a team on Tuesday to help fight a 57 hectare remote forest fire at Neringla, near Araluen were on hold.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier identifierScheme="DOC-ID">BATPOS-2033694</dc:identifier><dc:source Five helicopters from Germany joined the fight yesterday after the Greek Government asked for urgent help from European Union partners.</p><p>The region north-east of the city, where thousands have been evacuated, has been declared a disaster area.</p><p>The blaze started early on Friday near Mount Penteli overlooking Athens which is dotted with luxurious villas, summer homes and children's summer camps.</p><p>Authorities suspect arson. Officials said the environmental damage was immense as Penteli was one of two remaining green areas in the greater Athens area.</p><p>"It is a biblical, disastrous fire with a 20-kilometre front," Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou said. "It has been 50 years since we had something like this in the Athens area." Reuter</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content><nitf:body.end><graphic><nitf:media><caption><p>Greek tragedy: An Athenian woman flees the forest fire which has ragedthrough the outskirts of Athens for the urn:contentItem:5BBT-TG31-JD6G-424F-00000-00<published>2014-01-22T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T16:07:55Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>NEWS</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">NORTHERN Tablelands Rural Fire Service Superintendent Chris Wallbridge has urged locals to remain 'vigilant' through the searing weather and dry conditions as the area reaches severe fire danger levels.</p><p>NSW Rural Fire Service placed a total fire ban on the area yesterday as they battle to keep the area safe.</p><p>Fires to the west and south-east of Tenterfield have kept local fire crews busy as the Superintendent urged caution.</p><p> 'If you see smoke, ring 000 straight away.'</p><p>Mr Wallbridge said with the grounds being as dry as they are, fires have become more hazardous.</p><p>'We've had to put as much effort into those as we can ' the fires are moving very quick,' he said.</p><p>'There hasn't been too much wind which has been good - we just ask that people be very, very careful ' be vigilant,' he said.</p><p><b>UPDATE </b>(1pm Wednesday, January 22)<b>: </b>Fires are currently burning along Cullendore Road, near the Bruxner Highway at Mingoola, Boonoo Boonoo and Basket Swamp National Parks, Boorook as well as an out of control forest fire at Billirimba. </p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier identifierScheme="DOC-ID">TENTER-2039114</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="royaltyReportingKey">TENTER2014</dc:source><dc:identifier identifierScheme="PGUID">urn:contentItem:5BBT-TG31-JD6G-424F-00000-00</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="productContentSetIdentifier">390641</dc:source><dc:date dateType="last-updated">2019-10-05</dc:date></dc:metadata><wordCount number="172"/><publicationInfo><copyright>Copyright 2014 Fairfax Media Publications Pty. It takes only a spark to start a forest fire.</p><p nitf:lede="true">James 3:4-5 (Bible for Today)</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier identifierScheme="DOC-ID">ADVSUN-ADV0408071027440136</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="royaltyReportingKey">THEADVERTISERLTD</dc:source><dc:identifier identifierScheme="PGUID">urn:contentItem:4D1K-JW70-015G-X4GR-00000-00</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="productContentSetIdentifier">244790</dc:source><dc:date dateType="last-updated">2020-06-21</dc:date></dc:metadata><wordCount number="43"/><publicationInfo><publicationName>The Advertiser</publicationName><copyright>Copyright 2004 Nationwide News Pty Limited</copyright><publicationDate day="07" month="08" year="2004"><dateText>August 7, 2004 Saturday</dateText></publicationDate><classification classificationScheme="publicationtype"><classificationItem><className>Newspapers</className></classificationItem></classification></publicationInfo><classification classificationScheme="language"><classificationItem><className>ENGLISH</className></classificationItem></classification><classificationGroup classificationScheme="indexing-terms"><classification classificationScheme="subject"><classificationItem score="86"><classCode>ST0009QS2</classCode><className>REPORTS, REVIEWS & SECTIONS</className></classificationItem><classificationItem score="59"><classCode>STX000556</classCode><className>EDITORIALS & OPINIONS</className></classificationItem><classificationItem score="53"><classCode>STX001009</classCode><className>FOREST FIRES</className></classificationItem></classification></classificationGroup></metadata></articleDoc></content></entry>

urn:contentItem:49MW-TJB0-01S8-C1T7-00000-00<published>1991-03-09T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T16:07:55Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo/></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head/><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">Big Catamaran forest fire deliberate, says Llewellyn A BIG forest fire deliberately lit at Catamaran south of Dover was under control last night.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Fire authorities said they would put out any remaining embers in the burnt Forestry Commission coup this morning.</p><p>The Minister for Forests, Mr David Llewellyn, said yesterday the Government was worried about the irresponsible actions of those who lit the fire yesterday morning.</p><p>It had been started in seven different places.</p><p>"This blatant act is particularly serious on a day of total fire ban and full details have been given to the police," he said.</p><p>"The commission and the police will vigorously pursue investigations." Threats by protesters about causing deliberate fires in forests were particularly divisive and would pose serious problems as well as endangering life and property.</p><p>"I am particularly concerned that last year about nine separate arson fires occurred in the southern forests and caused considerable danger," Mr Llewellyn said.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata Dozens of forest fires have ignited across Portugal in the past week, encouraged by the hot, dry weather conditions which have turned much of Europe tinder dry.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Picture: The area is famous for the Anzac and Allied campaign against the Turks in World War I. Governor Husnu Tuglu of Canakkale province said it was not immediately clear if any military cemeteries and war memorials were threatened.</p><section G26</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head/><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">HAUNTED</p><p nitf:lede="true">9PM, TEN</p><p nitf:lede="true">A movie-length special, as Ten tries to cash in on the fame Lost has given Matthew Fox, the star of this supernatural series. Tonight, Frank (Fox), who communicates with the ghosts of murdered people, goes temporarily blind.</p><p>SPOOKS</p><p>9.25PM, ABC</p><p>An intriguing series. Tonight, a controversial writer is fired upon while supposedly under MI5 guard. On closer inspection, the spooks, or spies, uncover a plot that may explain the "hit".</p><p>MOVIE OF THE DAY</p><p>FIRESTORM</p><p>10.45PM, SEVEN (M) **</p><p>One of only three outings as director for respected Aussie cinematographer Dean Semmler, and hardly a highlight on his CV. Hero-type and NFL Hall of Fame member Howie Long stars as a tough-as-teak firefighter airdropped into the heart of a forest fire. Problem is, not only does Howie have to battle the flames, but the nasty group of escaped crims who started it. A predictable time-waster.</p><p>TRIVIA… TV doctor Hugh Laurie's (House) father was a doctor in real life.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head/><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">Fire fighters braced for action FOREST-FIRE protection plans for this summer are well advanced, the Minister for Forests, Mr David Llewellyn, said yesterday.</p><p>Mr Llewellyn said while it appeared the coming summer fire season would be difficult, all Forestry Commission districts were ready for action.</p><p>Fire-fighting equipment had been tested and the commission's helicopter-based fire fighting crews were undergoing further intensive training this month.</p><p>Mr Llewellyn said the commission would be cooperating with the Tasmanian Fire Service; the Department of Parks, Wildlife and Heritage; and forest-based industries to quickly detect and extinguish fires.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source FIRE fighting will be allowed in the Lemonthyme and southern forests this summer.</p><p>The Federal Minister for the Environment, Senator Graham Richardson, has given the State Government a special dispensation to do what it needs to control wildfires in the area.</p><p>Under Federal Government legislation, the forest in the area cannot be interfered with, without the minister's permission.</p><p>This is pending the findings of the Helsham Commission of Inquiry into its heritage value.</p><p>Senator Richardson made the exception after a State Government appeal pointed to the high fire danger this summer.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head/><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">Lune River forest fire now checked A FIRE which has been burning at Lune River since Monday has now been contained.</p><p>The fire, one of five in southern Tasmania, started as a regeneration burn-off by the Forestry Commission, but on Monday afternoon it escaped and momentarily threatened houses in the area.</p><p>The officer-in-charge of the commission's regeneration burns, Mr Graham Sargison, yesterday said no fires in the area were now causing concern.</p><p>Mr Sargison said the weather forecast for the weekend was in the commission's favour, and the aim was to completely secure all the fires over the weekend.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier He invited her to the Red Cross Ball in Monte Carlo next month, the Daily Mail newspaper reported.</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>QNP</p></bodyText></section><p>Peace off KHARTOUM: Sudan's Islamic Government yesterday rejected a proposal from former United States president Jimmy Carter to extend a ceasefire with southern rebels. But as Carter ended a visit to Khartoum, a senior Sudanese official said the Government and the rebel Sudan People's Liberation Army would resume peace talks soon to try to end the 12-year-old conflict. Fire out ATHENS: A huge forest fire which had raged through the outskirts of Athens for the last three days, gutting homes and destroying woodland, has been brought largely under control, the fire brigade said yesterday.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:49R4-VD60-0197-V279-00000-00<published>1995-04-07T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T16:07:55Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo/></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:byline>PROD</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">Fund for forest fire research A FIRE Research Fund, established by three state agencies, will lead to better fire management of dry sclerophyll forests in South-East Tasmania.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Managed by the Tasmanian Forest Research Council Inc, the jointly funded initiative of ForestryTasmania, Parks and Wildlife Service Tasmania and the Tasmania Fire Service will support research into fire management issues.</p><p>The project will be undertaken by University of Tasmania student Stephen Bresnehan, who is completing a science degree. It will be based at the university's Department of Geography and Environmental Studies and supervised by Professor Jamie Kirkpatrick.</p><p>TFRC executive officer Murray Jessup said research in dry sclerophyll forests was a high priority because of its flammability.</p><p>Each of the three organisations had provided $20,000 for the fund and planned further funding during the 1995-96 financial year.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source Officials in the provincial capital, Kunming,</p><p nitf:lede="true">said 79 people were dead and 148 still missing after two landslides on</p><p nitf:lede="true">a mountain last Friday and on Monday hit three mines sites.</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>QNP</p></bodyText></section><p>Homes razed</p><p>HOUSTON, Alaska: An out-of-control forest fire yesteday spread to</p><p>housing developments north of Anchorage, causing the evacuation of 1000</p><p>people, officials said. A local fire commander said the number of homes</p><p>destroyed was ""probably in the hundreds".</p><p>Arresting holidays</p><p>LONDON: Holiday airlines are to carry handcuffs as standard equipment</p><p>in an effort to deal with drunken passengers causing an increasingly</p><p>serious problem to air crews.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata Launceston is expecting 27 .</p><p>Following the forecast the State Fire Commissioner, Mr Jim Stewart, issued a warning to East Coast areas, which will be exposed to high winds and temperatures.</p><p>He asked landowners in the eastern half of Tasmania not to burn off today.</p><p>Mr Stewart said areas of the East Coast were particularly vulnerable to early seasonal fires such as had been occurring in the past few days.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source Both girls were slightly disappointed with their efforts but the pair were not helped by forest fire smoke clouds that swept through the stadium. Olympian Kerry Johnson burst back into the spotlight with a smart win in the women's 200m. Johnson recorded a time of 22.7sec although that was wind-assisted above the acceptable level for records. Johnson also took out the 100m invitation.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content><nitf:body.end><graphic><nitf:media><caption><p>PIC OF DEANN BOPF LEAPING TO VICTORY</p></caption></nitf:media></graphic></nitf:body.end></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier School bombed JOHANNESBURG._ A powerful explosion, believed to have been caused by a limpet mine, extensively damaged part of a white technical high school in Johannesburg yesterday. There were no injuries. Treaty claim WASHINGTON._ President Reagan told Congress yesterday that a new study showed the 1972 Anti-ballistic Missile (ABM) treaty did not bar testing of sophisticated components of the US ""Star Wars" program.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head/><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">Today's signs spell danger ON the anniversary of the tragic 1967 bushfires, the state fire commissioner yesterday warned that today contains the signs of danger for 1989.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Temperatures are forecast to reach 30 with moderate northerly winds.</p><p>And the commissioner, Mr Jim Stewart, said the Soil Dryness Index was now similar to February 1982 - when extreme temperatures and winds fanned wild fires in eastern, central and western areas of the state.</p><p>The combination of factors led Mr Stewart to issue high to very high forest fire danger warnings for most of Tasmania.</p><p>He said there had been very few fires of concern to date, but warned people to be aware of problems created by excess dry fuels.</p><p>Mr Stewart reminded landowners to reduce hazards around homes by mowing, slashing or grazing.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source urn:contentItem:49KY-6PK0-01S8-C1M4-00000-00<published>1989-02-18T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T16:07:55Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo/></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head/><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">Extreme fire danger THE State Fire Commission has warned of very high to extreme forest fire danger today.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Commissioner Mr Jim Stewart urged people not to light fires following a forecast of high temperatures, northerly winds and low humidity.</p><p>He said that although few serious fires had occurred this season, everyone should be alert to problems created by an abundance of dry fuels.</p><p>"No fires should be lit as the forecast conditions are well above the prescribed guidelines for safe burning off," he said.</p><p>"Each hot windy day is contributing to the curing of vegetation." The current soil dryness index still equates with February 1982 when extreme temperatures and winds fanned wild fires in both the Eastern, Central and Western areas of the State.</p><p>Mr Stewart reminded land owners to reduce hazards around homes by mowing, slashing or grazing.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata urn:contentItem:49K3-JP70-01S8-G4KY-00000-00<published>1987-05-29T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T16:07:55Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo/></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:byline>COSTELLO D</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">Power worry MOSCOW._ The Soviet space station Mir was facing a power shortage which would have to be corrected by a new space walk by its two cosmonauts, Moscow Radio said yesterday.</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>QNP</p></bodyText></section><p>Fire threat renewed PEKING._ A forest fire in the Soviet Far East had crept closer to China and new blazes had flared in parts of the north-east devastated by China's worst fire in recent history, the official media reported yesterday. Safety claim doubts LONDON._ Claims that hospitals are the safest places for women to give birth are not supported by any evidence, a Health Department study says. It says more problems may occur in hospital for both mothers and babies than at home. Actor charged LOS ANGELES._ Actor Sean Penn was charged yesterday with drunken driving, police said here. The 26-year-old actor, husband of singer Madonna, was freed on bail to appear in court on June 18.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata US visit to Hanoi BANGKOK._ US officials flew to Hanoi yesterday to pave the way for a special envoy from President Reagan to speed up the tracing of Americans missing after the Vietnam War. Fire controlled PEKING._ China's biggest forest fire for nearly 40 years had been brought under control by rain and the efforts of tens of thousands of people, the People's Daily reported yesterday. Activist held JOHANNESBURG._ Justice Langa, the leader of a black South African railway union involved in a violent dispute with State employers had been detained by police, union sources said.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:4B41-2PX0-01S8-C4SV-00000-00<published>1993-05-13T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T16:07:55Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo/></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head/><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">A SCUBA diver was burned to death after he was plucked from the sea and dropped into a raging forest fire by a Greek fire-fighting plane earlier this week.</p><p nitf:lede="true">The freak accident occurred when one of a fleet of fire-fighting planes swooped down to collect water from the Aegean Sea to fight a fire in the Parnassos Mountains.</p><p>The diver, a tourist, was near the surface when he was scooped into the plane's water tank.</p><p>The pilot, who was oblivious to the man's fate, then flew 80 kilometres back to the fire, where he jettisoned the water.</p><p>The man's burnt body, complete with flippers and scuba gear, was found by firemen in a routine clean-up operation after the blaze had been extinguished.</p><p>An investigator said: "It was a terrible way to go. It is all very sad and should not have happened.</p><p>"The poor man must have been terrified. He must have wondered what the hell was going on.</p><p>"We don't know how he died. Maybe he burned to death or maybe it was the long drop.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source urn:contentItem:49KY-6PJ0-01S8-C0W4-00000-00<published>1989-02-11T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T16:07:55Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo/></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:byline>FOGAGNOLO JOCELYN</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">The bushfire cost Each year the cost to the community rises with the flames. In 1967 it was an estimated $2,000,000 a week.</p><p>By 1983 this had risen to about $16 million a week.</p><p>In 1974-75, bushfires denuded more than 15 per cent of Australia nearly four times the size of Italy!</p><p>About 94 per cent of all bushfires are caused by people and of these at least half are the result of burning-off that gets out of hand and another 15 per cent start from sparks from mechanical sources.</p><p>Australia's eucalypt forests are noted as the worst in the world for spreading "spot fires" and there are cases of spotting from a dense forest fire of up to 30km away.</p><p>Cyclic and severe wildfires vary from area to area but there appear to be average cycles of about 44 years for great conflagrations (such as Black Friday in Victoria in 1939 and Ash Wednesday in South Australia and Victoria in 1983). Within this cycle is another of exceptionally bad fires about every 22 years.</p><p>The cycle of serious wildfires in Tasmania appears to be about every 10 years.</p><p>The intensity of Tasmania's 1967 bushfires was estimated as greater than that of several atomic explosions.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata
